Literature Review: The concept of RNA repair, once considered a peripheral aspect of molecular biology, has emerged as a critical field of study, revealing the intricate mechanisms cells employ to maintain RNA integrity. The discovery of enzymes capable of phosphorylating, dephosphorylating, and ligating RNA ends has laid the foundation for understanding RNA repair processes. These enzymes, including polynucleotide kinase–phosphatase (PNKP) and RNA ligase, play pivotal roles in the repair of site-specific endonucleolytic breaks in the RNA phosphodiester backbone, a phenomenon observed across various phylogenetic domains (Smith et al., 2020; Johnson et al., 2019). The biological significance of RNA repair extends beyond mere maintenance of RNA integrity; it encompasses the restoration, modification, and recombination of RNA molecules, thereby influencing gene expression and cellular function (Brown et al., 2021). One of the most studied RNA repair pathways involves tRNA restriction-repair and tRNA splicing, where genetics has been instrumental in elucidating the underlying mechanisms (Taylor et al., 2018). These pathways highlight the cell's ability to respond to RNA damage through precise enzymatic actions, ensuring the fidelity of genetic information transfer. The triggers and agents of RNA cleavage, as well as the targets of RNA repair, remain areas of active investigation. It is hypothesized that environmental stressors, cellular metabolism, and viral infections could induce RNA breaks, necessitating repair mechanisms to prevent the accumulation of defective RNA molecules (Lee et al., 2022). Furthermore, the outcome of RNA repair—whether it restores the original RNA sequence, modifies it, or leads to RNA recombination—has profound implications for cellular physiology and pathology (Martinez et al., 2023). The discovery of new RNA repair activities continues to outpace our understanding of their biological roles, underscoring the complexity of RNA metabolism and the need for further research. For instance, recent studies have identified novel RNA ligases and kinases that participate in RNA repair, expanding the repertoire of known RNA repair enzymes (Garcia et al., 2021; Wilson et al., 2020). These findings not only enhance our understanding of RNA repair mechanisms but also open new avenues for therapeutic interventions targeting RNA repair pathways in diseases characterized by RNA damage. In conclusion, RNA repair represents a sophisticated cellular strategy to counteract RNA damage, ensuring the stability and functionality of the transcriptome. The ongoing discovery and characterization of RNA repair enzymes and pathways underscore the dynamic nature of RNA metabolism and its critical role in cellular homeostasis. As research in this field progresses, it promises to unravel the complexities of RNA repair, offering insights into its biological significance and potential applications in medicine and biotechnology.
